subNodes.conversationText: The hole opened into a cavity at least as big as the shack.
Rock jutted out from the ground at the rim of the hole. If <he/she> could get a good grip on it, <he/she> might be able to drop down feet first.
As if reading <his/her> mind, Knott transformed into an ordinary gourd again and rolled toward the young witch. Tilen seemed none the wiser.
<He/She> picked him up and stowed him away.
Then <FirstName> grabbed ahold of the outcropping and swung over the side.

[Success: Strength > 11] <He/She> had a sure grip that could make fingerholds of smoother surfaces than the outcropping's rough one. <He/She> steadied <him/her>self then dropped, landing with a splash in a few inches of running water. Part of the hole gave way, bringing some of the floor with it, but the witch managed to avoid the debris.
"Witch? Can you hear me?" shouted Tilen from above.

[Failure: Strength too low] <FirstName>'s grip was weak. One hand slipped, and the other followed, and then <he/she> fell. <He/She> landed with a splash in a few inches of running water. 

The young witch stood up and darted out of the way just in time: part of the hole fell in, bringing some of the floor with it.
"Witch? Can you hear me?" shouted Tilen from above.
"Yes, still here," the witch shouted back.
"Indeed it did," said the witch. brushing <him/her>self off.
"That is not news to me, Tilen."
The witch said nothing and began exploring the cavity.
<FirstName> fed him a few kernels. "There, there."
Then <FirstName> grabbed ahold of the outcropping and swung over the side.
<He/She> studied the outcropping of rock <he/she>'d observed before.
<He/She> considered trying to explore the cavity below.
Rock jutted out from the ground at the rim of the hole. If <he/she> could get a good grip on it, <he/she> might be able to drop down feet first.
<He/She> studied the outcropping of rock <he/she>'d observed before.
<FirstName>'s previous descent had disturbed the rim of the hole. It looked too dangerous to attempt again.
